sect1.title: What's New For Administrators
sect1.para: As of GNOME 2.14, the GNOME Project now releases an Administration Suite, which is a collection of tools that are aimed squarely at systems administrators. The two new tools that form the beginnings of this suite are incredibly powerful and should help administrators in both large corporate deployments and situations where machine lockdown is required.

sect2.title: Sabayon - Profile Editor
sect2.para: Sabayon allows administrators to set up user profiles inside a live, interactive GNOME session. When a profile is created or edited, a nested GNOME session is started up, which the administrator can use to change anything they would in their own GNOME session.

textobject.phrase: Using Sabayon to edit a user profile in an embedded window

sect2.para: Sabayon will track changes to both files and GConf settings. The administrator can then choose to remove accidental changes, or make some of them mandatory rather than optional (e.g. lockdown and proxy settings). Once complete, the administrator can package up these profiles and deploy them to other machines.

Users or groups (???) are placed into profiles which will be used when they log into their GNOME session. Being able to easily create multiple profiles and allocate each user separately allows users to have different setups based on their job description (eg. receptionist, data entry clerk, programmer, human resources manager, etc.).

sect2.title: Pessulus - Lockdown Editor
sect2.para: Pessulus is a lockdown editor that allows administrators to easily disable certain features of the GNOME desktop, as may be desired in corporate environments and Internet caf√©s. While lockdown features have now been available in GNOME for many years, Pessulus makes it far easier for administrators to do.

figure.title: Using the lockdown editor to prevent system shutdown by users

sect2.para: Some of the features that can be disabled include:

listitem.para: the ability to shutdown or reboot the machine;
access to specific protocols in the web browser; and
the ability to edit the GNOME panels.
